This week marks the start of Mental Health Awareness Week!

This year's theme is loneliness but here's a light take on how you could improve your overall mental
health!

- Getting out and about in nature could generate a sense of calmness, which is great especially during exam season!
- Making sure you eat a wide range of fruits and veggies means your body could get the nutrients
and vitamins it needs to function properly.
- Being active could lead to the release of "happiness" hormones that might make you feel
more able to cope with your day and leave you with a sense of achievement.
- Getting enough sleep might ensure you get enough rest to take on your daily tasks.

Most importantly, it's important to do what "feels" healthy to you! Whether that's getting an early start, making a wholesome dinner or just brushing your teeth!

Make sure you turn notifications on to make sure you don't miss any of our tips this week!

Ready to make another super healthy and tasty recipe? Ingredients ‚Ä¢ 1 small pack mint , leaves picked ‚Ä¢ 150g natural yogurt , plus extra to serve (optional) ‚Ä¢ 1 lemon , zested and juiced ‚Ä¢ ¬Ω tsp ground cumin ‚Ä¢ ¬Ω tsp ground coriander ‚Ä¢ 2cm piece ginger , grated ‚Ä¢ 4 skinless chicken breasts, each cut into 6 pieces ‚Ä¢ 4 wholemeal flatbreads or pittas ‚Ä¢ 2 Little Gem lettuces , sliced ‚Ä¢ 1 small red onion , sliced, to serve ‚Ä¢ pickled red cabbage , chilli sauce and hummus, to serve (all optional) You will need ‚Ä¢ 4 metal or wooden skewers Method ‚Ä¢ STEP 1 Chop half the mint and put in a bowl with the yogurt, half the lemon juice, all the lemon zest, spices and ginger. Mix well and season with lots of black pepper and a pinch of salt. Add the chicken pieces, mix well and put in the fridge for 20-30 mins. Meanwhile, soak 4 large wooden skewers in water for at least 20 mins (or use metal ones). ‚Ä¢ STEP 2 When you‚Äôre ready to cook the chicken, heat your grill to a medium heat and line the grill tray with foil. Thread the chicken onto the soaked wooden or metal skewers and grill for 15-20 mins, turning halfway through, until browned and cooked through. ‚Ä¢ STEP 3 Warm the flatbreads under the grill for a couple of seconds, then serve them topped with the lettuce, chicken, red onion, remaining lemon juice and mint, and any optional extras such as extra yogurt or pickled cabbage, chilli sauce and hummus. Wellbeing Wednesday

Feeling sore and stiff after coming to the gym? Here‚Äôs 5 ways to help prevent delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS) 

1. Get moving. - Don't allow your muscles to seize up, get out for a walk or cycle to get the blood flowing.

2. Stay hydrated - You need to replace all the fluids you've lost through exercising. A lack of electrolytes will contribute to the soreness.

3. Foam Roll/Stretching - Your muscles will become very tight very quickly without stretching or massaging them. We can help relax the muscles by using these techniques. Foam rolling can be used as a form of massage.

4. Warm/cold baths - A cold bath will constrict your blood vessels and cause new blood to circulate through and flush out waste products. A warm bath will then open up those vessels and allow the fresh blood to circulate easier.

5. Rest - This is the main time your body is able to recover and your muscles repair from exercise. Having a good sleep routine aiming for 8 hours of sleep a night will reduce muscle soreness.

Kind Regards

The CitySport Team

New Recipe for you to try out: Speedy Squash Barley Risotto Method ‚Ä¢STEP 1 Heat the oil in a deep frying pan over a medium heat, and fry the shallot with a pinch of salt for 5 mins until soft. Add the squash, garlic, sage and mace, and fry, stirring continually, for another 6-8 mins until the squash is starting to soften and the garlic is fragrant. ‚Ä¢STEP 2 Tip in the spinach and barley with some seasoning and the stock. Bring to a simmer and cook for 4-5 mins until the spinach has wilted. Add a splash more stock or water, if you like. When the ‚Äòrisotto‚Äô is thick and creamy, taste to see if it needs a little more mace or nutmeg and seasoning. Stir in most of the parmesan, then top with the remaining parmesan and grind over some black pepper to serve. Ingredients ‚Ä¢2 tsp olive oil ‚Ä¢1 large shallot or small onion, finely chopped ‚Ä¢300g squash or pumpkin, cut into 1cm cubes ‚Ä¢2 garlic cloves, crushed ‚Ä¢small handful of sage leaves, finely chopped ‚Ä¢¬Ω tsp ground mace or a good grating of nutmeg ‚Ä¢160g spinach leaves ‚Ä¢2 x 400g cans barley in water, drained ‚Ä¢300ml hot vegetable stock ‚Ä¢40g parmesan or vegetarian alternative, finely grated Nutritional Information: kcal: 336 fat: 10g saturates: 5g carbs: 40g sugars: 9g fibre: 10g protein: 16g salt: 0.9g @feelgoodfriday @unigym @studentgym @studentfitness @studenthealth @fitnessgym @stayactivestayfit @unisport @unisportlife @healthystudent @studentwellness @studentwellbeing @citysport @citygym @cityftness @fitness @fitnessclasses @fitnessclass @onlinefitness @onlineclass @reopening @membership @healthyeating

Easy things you can do in your day to be more active‚Ä¶

1. Add some cardio to your gym sessions. This could be on the bike, treadmill, rowing machine or cross trainer.

2. Get off your bus or train 1 stop earlier than normal and walk part of your journey. 

3. Set an alarm on your phone to move around every 30 minutes. 

4. Meet up with your friends for a walk rather than a chat over a coffee. 

5. Always take the stairs rather than lift or escalator.

5 tips to ensure you have the best quality sleep...
¬†
1Ô∏è‚É£Light Control
Darkness causes the body to start producing melatonin which in cause makes us sleepy.
¬†
The earlier you start darkening your environment the quicker melatonin will be produced making you feel drowsy and get you to sleep earlier.
¬†
2Ô∏è‚É£Circadian Rhythm‚Ä®Your circadian rhythm is you internal body clock that process vital functions over 24 hours cycles.
¬†
Consistently waking up and sleeping at the same time each day will aid your sleep-wake cycle and create a good routine for your body to adjust to.
¬†
3Ô∏è‚É£Caffeine Limits
Studies have shown that caffeine consumed 6 hours before sleep negatively contributed both to the quality and duration of sleep.
¬†
Limiting caffeine consumption in the evening will reduce its effect and help you sleep quicker.
¬†
4Ô∏è‚É£Melatonin
Melatonin is a hormone released at night which contributes to us falling asleep.
¬†
Foods such as cherries, berries, kiwi, milk and fish all have high levels of melatonin or contribute to the production of other hormones that aid sleep.
¬†
5Ô∏è‚É£Sleeping Environment
Your bedroom should be associated with sleep and relaxation.
¬†

Vitamin D, the "sunshine vitamin" (absorbed through sunlight), offers a range of benefits, from positives for both physical and mental health. We will also discuss enriched foods and daily intake.
‚†Ä
---Healthy bones
Vitamin D promotes calcium absorption and helps maintain adequate blood levels of calcium and phosphorus. This in turn provides us with stronger, healthier bones, and reduces the risk of injury and fractures.‚†Ä
 ‚†Ä
---Vitamin D may fight disease
Research has shown that an increase in this vitamin can aid in decreasing the chance of heart disease. Low levels have been linked to increased risk of diseases such as hypertension, heart failure and stroke.It has also been shown to support immune health.‚†Ä
 ‚†Ä
---May regulate mood and reduce depression
In recent studies, subjects who were experiencing negative emotions were later supplemented with vitamin D and later noticed an improvement in symptoms.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Å£-----------------‚Å£-----------------‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚Äî-Some foods that include Vitamin D are:
Fishes (salmon, sardines, herring, canned tuna)‚†Ä
cod liver oil‚†Ä
beef liver‚†Ä
red meat‚†Ä
egg yolk‚†Ä
shrimp‚†Ä
regular mushrooms‚†Ä
milk, yoghurt, and non-dairy alternatives (fortified)‚†Ä
certain cereals, and oatmeal (fortified)‚†Ä
orange juice (fortified)‚†Ä
‚†Ä
If dietary limitations hold you back from consuming most of things listed, an alternative is supplementation. It usually comes in two forms (Vitamin D2 ans Vitamin D3 - most potent of the two).‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Because vitamin D is fat-soluble, eating it with fatty foods may help increase its absorption.‚†Ä
 ‚†Ä
---Recommended daily intake‚†Ä
‚†Ä
This will vary on factors such as age, ethnicity, climate exposer, and seasons. it is recommended to have at least 10-20 micrograms a day,but a drastic increase may be required if you are not exposed to the sun or have darker skin tones.‚†Ä
 ‚†Ä
---Summary‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Vitamin D is essential for bone health and many other aspects of health. Deficiency is prevalent and may have health consequences for many people.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
If you are thinking about adding more vitamin D to your diet, consider the following factors and speak with a professional health advisor.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

April marks stress awareness month. Here is 5 ways to help reduce stress‚Ä¶
 
1. Keep active
Exercising will reduce some of the emotional intensity that you're feeling, clearing your thoughts, and letting you deal with your problems more calmly. Regular exercise has been shown to improve symptoms of common mental health conditions such as anxiety and depression

2. Connect with friends and family 
A good support network of colleagues, friends and family can ease your work troubles and help you see things in a different way. We often have a good laugh with them, which is an excellent stress reliever.

3. Spend some ‚Äòme‚Äô time 
Taking time for yourself is essential to living a healthy life. Studies show that people who engage in self-care report lower levels of stress and improved quality of life, while a lack of self-care is associated with higher risk of stress and burnout

4. Have a healthy diet
Minimizing your intake of highly processed foods and beverages and eating more whole foods such as vegetables, fruits, beans, fish, nuts, and seeds can help ensure that your body is properly nourished. In turn, this may improve your resilience to stress.

5. Ensure you get enough sleep
A good night's sleep makes you able to tackle the day's stress more easily. When you‚Äôre tired, you‚Äôre less patient and more easily agitated, which can increase stress. Most adults need 7 to 9 hours of sleep each night.

Ramadan Nutrition 
 
Before Fasting (Sehri)
Sehri should be a combination of all food groups to give you the required nutrition. Eating starchy foods at Sehri will provide energy during the day, while high fibre or wholegrain foods such as wholegrain bread, cereal, oat, and porridge keep you feeling fuller during the day and aid digestion. Dairy products such as milk and yoghurt are a good choice for Sehri, likewise Eggs are a great source of Protein too. 
 
After Fasting (Iftar)
Iftar should be a well-balanced nutritious meal. Incorporate foods from all major food groups; i.e. a combination of starchy foods, protein rich foods like meat, fish, eggs and beans, dairy products and, vegetables. Consuming fibre-rich food is important as they aid in digestion.

Wellbeing Wednesday!

Good hydration is one of the most important aspects of the diet ‚Äì drinking enough liquids to keep the fluid levels in the body topped up helps to ensure that all bodily functions are able to take place as normal.

Fluid is so important in the body that even when levels drop only slightly, we begin to feel the consequences. Low levels of fluid in the body can cause headaches, feelings of dizziness, lethargy and poor concentration.

Adults need to drink around 1.5‚Äì2 litres of fluid a day. A typical mug or glass is about 200 millilitres (ml) so this equates to 8-10 drinks a day. Remember though the more you exercise the more you should be drinking!

This week marks the start of Mental Health Awareness Week! This year's theme is loneliness but here's a light take on how you could improve your overall mental health! - Getting out and about in nature could generate a sense of calmness, which is great especially during exam season! - Making sure you eat a wide range of fruits and veggies means your body could get the nutrients and vitamins it needs to function properly. - Being active could lead to the release of "happiness" hormones that might make you feel more able to cope with your day and leave you with a sense of achievement. - Getting enough sleep might ensure you get enough rest to take on your daily tasks. As we move into the upcoming assessment period, it's easy to get lost amongst revision and looming deadlines. At this time, it‚Äôs even more important that you prioritise your self-care. This might mean making time to meet with friends or heading out for a walk to take a break from your studies. @cityuniversitylondon @cityunichaplaincy @citysueducation @citymentalhealthsociety @esncitylondon @cityunistressless @citywellbeingsociety @mentalhealthfoundation

City‚Äôs Fundraising Team are currently looking for City students to join them as a Student Fundraiser alongside your studies during the Spring term.

If selected, you will be expected to contact selected graduates of the University by telephone to ask them to support City with a charitable gift. You will also share news, gain invaluable advice and, in some cases, even secure vital experiences through placements and extra work. Through these telephone fundraising campaign, past Student Fundraisers have raised over half a million pounds towards student facing projects.

Previous fundraising experience is not required as you will be fully trained and the Fundraising Team will support you with practical tips to ensure you achieve success. What they are looking for is for you to:

‚Ä¢	Be enthusiastic and friendly
‚Ä¢	Be reliable and ready for a challenge
‚Ä¢	Have good communication and listening skills

Successful students will get:

‚Ä¢	At least three shifts a week at ¬£12.38 per hour
‚Ä¢	The opportunity to network with hundreds of former City students
‚Ä¢	Develop transferable skills include communication and negotiation
‚Ä¢	The chance to secure work and placements ‚Äì previous students have found themselves gaining experience and roles at J.P. Morgan, Deloitte, Lloyds, Transport for London and the Guardian newspaper.

Applications should be submitted by Thursday 3rd March, 12am via Unitemps. If you have any questions, you can email Jason Barlow, Regular Giving Manager.
